case_name: Printer, publisher and editor of Cross Roads v. Government of Madras

facts.text: Petition No. XVI of 1950 filed in original jurisdiction under article 32 of the Constitution for writ of prohibition and certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. XVI of 1950. Appli- cation under article 32 of the Constitution for a writ of prohibition and certiorari. The facts are set out in the judgment.

facts.text: Petitioner represented by R.Pattabhi Raman.

anchor.surface_text: R.Pattabhi Raman, for the petitioner. Rajah Ayyar, Advocate-General of MadraS,  Ganapathi Ayyar, with him  for the opposite party.

facts.text: Opposite party represented by Rajah Ayyar, Advocate-General of Madras, and Ganapathi Ayyar.

anchor.surface_text: Rajah Ayyar, Advocate-General of MadraS,  Ganapathi Ayyar, with him  for the opposite party. 1950. May 26. The Judgment of Kania C.J., Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ.

facts.text: Case heard on May 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. May 26. The Judgment of Kania C.J., Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ. was delivered by Patanjali Sastri J. Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate judgment.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Patanjali Sastri J. for Kania C.J., Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of Kania C.J., Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ. was delivered by Patanjali Sastri J. Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate judgment. PATANJALI SASTRI J.--The petitioner is the printer, publisher and editor of a recently started weekly journal in English called Cross Roads printed and published in Bombay.

facts.text: Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate judgment. PATANJALI SASTRI J.--The petitioner is the printer, publisher and editor of a recently started weekly journal in English called Cross Roads printed and published in Bombay.

facts.text: Petitioner is the printer, publisher and editor of a recently started weekly journal in English called Cross Roads printed and published in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: PATANJALI SASTRI J.--The petitioner is the printer, publisher and editor of a recently started weekly journal in English called Cross Roads printed and published in Bombay. The Government of Madras, the respondents herein, in exer- cise of their powers under section 9  1-A  of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act, 1949  hereinafter referred to as the impugned Act  purported to issue an order No. MS. 1333 dated 1st March, 1950,

facts.text: Government of Madras issued order No. MS. 1333 dated 1st March, 1950 under section 9(1-A) of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act, 1949 banning entry and circulation of Cross Roads in Madras State.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Madras, the respondents herein, in exer- cise of their powers under section 9  1-A  of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act, 1949  hereinafter referred to as the impugned Act  purported to issue an order No. MS. 1333 dated 1st March, 1950, whereby they imposed a ban upon the entry and circulation of the journal in that State. The order was published in the Fort St. George Gazette and the numberification ran as follows -- In exercise of the powers companyferred by section 9  I-A  of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order, Act, 1949  Madras Act XXIII of 1949  His Excellency the Governor of Madras, being satisfied that for the purpose of securing the public safety and the maintenance of public order, it is necessary so to do, hereby prohibits, with effect on and from the date of publication of this order in the Fort St. George Gazette the entry into or the circulation, sale or distribution in the State of Madras or any part thereof of the newspaper entitled Cross Roads an English weekly published at Bombay.

facts.text: Order published in the Fort St. George Gazette.

The State of Delhi, p. 605 infra. speech and expression companyferred on him by article 19  1   a  of the Constitution and he challenges the validity of section 9  1-A  of the impugned Act as being void under article 13  1  of the Constitution by reason of its being inconsistent with his fundamental right aforesaid.

anchor.surface_text: and he challenges the validity of section 9  1-A  of the impugned Act as being void under article 13  1  of the Constitution by reason of its being inconsistent with his fundamental right aforesaid. The Advocate-General of Madras appearing on be half of the respondents raised a preliminary objection, number indeed to the jurisdiction of this Court to entertain the application under article 32, but to the petitioner resort- ing to this Court directly for such relief in the first instance.

facts.text: Advocate-General of Madras raised preliminary objection to jurisdiction of Supreme Court under article 32, suggesting petitioner should first approach Madras High Court under article 226.

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate-General of Madras appearing on be half of the respondents raised a preliminary objection, number indeed to the jurisdiction of this Court to entertain the application under article 32, but to the petitioner resort- ing to this Court directly for such relief in the first instance. He companytended that, as a matter of orderly proce- dure, the petitioner should first resort to the High Court at Madras which under article 226 of the Constitution has companycurrent jurisdiction to deal with the matter.

facts.text: Court overruled the preliminary objection.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that neither the instances mentioned by the learned Advocate General number the American decisions referred to by him are really analogous to the remedy afforded by article 32 of the Indian Constitution.

facts.text: Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act, 1949 is Madras Act XXIII of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act, 1949  hereinafter referred to as the impugned Act  purported to issue an order No. MS. 1333 dated 1st March, 1950, whereby they imposed a ban upon the entry and circulation of the journal in that State. The order was published in the Fort St. George Gazette and the numberification ran as follows -- In exercise of the powers companyferred by section 9  I-A  of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order, Act, 1949  Madras Act XXIII of 1949

facts.text: Impugned Act passed by Provincial Legislature under section 100 of Government of India Act 1935 read with Entry 1 of List II of Seventh Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned Act was passed by the Provincial Legisla- ture in exercise of the power companyferred upon it by section 100 of the Government of India Act 1935, read with Entry 1 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to that Act, which company- prises among other matters, public order.

facts.text: Court held section 9(1-A) void and unconstitutional, quashed the order.

anchor.surface_text: It fol- lows that section 9  1-A  which authorises imposition of restrictions for the wider purpose of securing public safety or the maintenance of public order falls outside the scope of authorised restrictions under clause  2 , and is there- fore void and unconstitutional. ... The application is therefore allowed and the order of the respondents prohibiting the entry and circulation of the petitioners journal in the State of Madras is hereby quashed.

facts.text: Fazl Ali J. dissents, would dismiss the petition.

anchor.surface_text: FAZL ALI J.--For the reasons given by me in Brij Bhushan and Another v. The State 1  , which practically 605. involves the same question as is involved in this case, I hold that the reliefs sought by the petitioner cannot be granted. In this view, I would dismiss this petition,

issues.text: Whether the petitioner should first resort to the High Court at Madras under article 226 of the Constitution before approaching this Court under article 32 for relief

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate-General of Madras appearing on be half of the respondents raised a preliminary objection, indeed to the jurisdiction of this Court to entertain the application under article 32, but to the petitioner resort- ing to this Court directly for such relief in the first instance. He contended that, as a matter of orderly proce- dure, the petitioner should first resort to the High Court at Madras which under article 226 of the Constitution has concurrent jurisdiction

issues.text: Whether freedom of speech and expression under article 19(1)(a) includes freedom of circulation of publications

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the merits, there can be no doubt that freedom of speech and expression includes freedom of propa- gation of ideas, and that freedom is ensured by the freedom of circulation. Liberty of circulation is as essential to that freedom as the liberty of publication.

issues.text: Whether section 9(1-A) of the impugned Act, insofar as it authorises restrictions for securing public safety or maintenance of public order, relates to matters undermining the security of or tending to overthrow the State so as to be saved by article 19(2)

anchor.surface_text: The question accordingly arises whether, the impugned Act, in so far as it purports by section 9 (1-A) to authorise the Provincial Government for the purpose of securing the public safety or the maintenance of public order, to prohibit or regulate the entry into or the circulation, sale or distribution in the Province of Madras or any part thereof of any document or class of documents is a law relating to any matter which undermines the security of or tends to overthrow the State.

issues.text: Whether section 9(1-A) is void wholly under article 13(1) or only to the extent of inconsistency with article 19(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, argued that section 9 (1-A) could not be considered wholly void, as, under article 13 (1), an existing law inconsistent with a fundamental right is void only to the extent of the inconsistency and no more. In so far as the securing of the public safety or the maintenance of public order would include the security of the State, the impugned provision, as applied to the latter purpose, was covered by clause (2) of article 19 and must, it was said, be held to be valid.

issues.text: Whether disorders involving menace to the peace and tranquillity of the Province and affecting public safety undermine the security of the State

arguments.claim: The order contravenes the petitioner's fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression under article 19(1)(a), and section 9(1-A) is void under article 13(1).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner claims that the said order contravenes the fundamental right of the petitioner to freedom of speech and expression conferred on him by article 19 (1) (a) of the Constitution and he challenges the validity of section 9 (1-A) of the impugned Act as being void under article 13 (1) of the Constitution by reason of its being inconsistent with his fundamental right aforesaid.

arguments.court_reasoning: Freedom of speech includes circulation; s.9(1-A) overbroad beyond Art.19(2) limits.

arguments.claim: This Court lacks jurisdiction under article 32 as petitioner should first approach Madras High Court under article 226 as a matter of orderly procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate-General of Madras appearing on be half of the respondents raised a preliminary objection, indeed to the jurisdiction of this Court to entertain the application under article 32, but to the petitioner resorting to this Court directly for such relief in the first instance. He contended that, as a matter of orderly procedure, the petitioner should first resort to the High Court at Madras which under article 226 of the Constitution has concurrent jurisdiction

arguments.court_reasoning: Art.32 is a guaranteed fundamental right remedy, not analogous to other concurrent jurisdictions; court must protect fundamental rights.

arguments.claim: Rule of practice requires exhausting lower remedies first, as in CrPC s.435, CPC s.24, Emperor v. Bisheswar Prasad Sinha, and US cases like Urquhart v. Brown.

anchor.surface_text: He cited criminal revision petitions under section 435 of the Criminal Procedure Code, applications for bail and applications for transfer under section 24 of the Civil Procedure Code as instances where, concurrent jurisdiction having been given in certain matters to the High Court and the Court of a lower grade, a rule of practice has been established that a party should proceed first to the latter Court for relief before resorting to the High Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 179.  3  294 S. 103. High Courts, to issue certain writs for the enforcement of the rights companyferred by Part III or for any other purpose, as par

arguments.court_reasoning: Not analogous to Art.32, which is a distinct guaranteed remedy in Part III.

arguments.claim: Freedom of speech and expression under Art.19(1)(a) includes freedom of propagation of ideas ensured by freedom of circulation.

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the merits, there can be no doubt that freedom of speech and expression includes freedom of propagation of ideas, and that freedom is ensured by the freedom of circulation. Liberty of circulation is as essential to that freedom as the liberty of publication. Indeed, without circulation the publication would be of little value Ex parte Jackson. See also Lovell v. City of Griffin.

arguments.claim: Section 9(1-A) is saved by Art.19(2) as 'public safety' in the Act means security of the State/Province.

anchor.surface_text: But it was urged that the expression public safety in the impugned Act, which is a statute relating to law and order, means the security of the Province, and, therefore, the security of the State with the meaning of article 19 (2) as the State has been defined in article 12 as including, among other things, the Government and the Legislature of each of the erstwhile Provinces. Much reliance was placed in support of this view on Rex v. Wormwood Scrubbs Prison

arguments.court_reasoning: Public safety wider than security of State; IPC distinguishes offences against public safety from those against State; context matters.

arguments.claim: Restrictive laws like this must relate to security of State, not trivial offences.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that an enactment which provided for drastic remedies like preventive detention and ban on newspapers must be taken to relate to matters affecting the security of the State rather than trivial offences like rash driving, or an affray.

In so far as the securing of the public safety or the maintenance of public order would include the security of the State, the impugned provision, as applied to the latter purpose, was covered by clause (2) of article 19 and must, it was said, be held to be valid.

arguments.court_reasoning: Overbroad language covers impermissible restrictions; not severable; wholly void.

arguments.claim: Public order/safety disturbances, especially grave ones menacing Province, undermine security of State; Act valid under Art.19(2).
Sedition and public disorders both affect public tranquillity; distinction untenable.

holdings.text: Neither the instances mentioned by the learned Advocate General nor the American decisions referred to by him are really analogous to the remedy afforded by article 32 of the Indian Constitution. Article 32 provides a guaranteed remedy for the enforcement of those rights, and this remedial right is itself made a fundamental right by being included in Part III. This Court is thus constituted the protector and guarantor of fundamental rights, and it cannot, consistently with the responsibility so laid upon it, refuse to entertain applications seeking protection against infringements of such rights.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that neither the instances mentioned by the learned Advocate General number the American decisions referred to by him are really analogous to the remedy afforded by article 32 of the Indian Constitution. That article does number merely companyfer power on this

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.32 distinct from concurrent jurisdictions like CrPC/CPC or US remedies; itself fundamental right obliging Court to entertain directly.

holdings.text: Freedom of speech and expression includes freedom of propagation of ideas, and that freedom is ensured by the freedom of circulation. Liberty of circulation is as essential to that freedom as the liberty of publication.

anchor.surface_text: Turning number to the merits, there can be numberdoubt that freedom of speech and expression includes freedom of propa- gation of ideas, and that freedom is ensured by the freedom of circulation. Liberty of circulation is as essential to that

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liberty of publication valueless without circulation; supported by US precedents like Ex parte Jackson and Lovell v. City of Griffin.

holdings.text: Unless a law restricting freedom of speech and expression is directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it, such law cannot fall within the reservation under clause (2) of article 19. Section 9(1-A) which authorises imposition of restrictions for the wider purpose of securing public safety or the maintenance of public order falls outside the scope of authorised restrictions under clause (2), and is therefore void and unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that unless a law restrict- ing freedom of speech and expression is directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it, such law cannot fall within the reservation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public order/safety wider than Art.19(2) limits; distinguished via IPC chapters, GOI Act 1935, Constitution entries; drastic remedies do not limit scope without words.

holdings.text: Where a law purports to authorise the imposition of restrictions on a fundamental right in language wide enough to cover restrictions both within and without the limits of constitutionally permissible legislative action affecting such right, it is not possible to uphold it even so far as it may be applied within the constitutional limits, as it is not severable. So long as the possibility of its being applied for purposes not sanctioned by the Constitution cannot be ruled out, it must be held to be wholly unconstitutional and void.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accede to this companytention. Where a law purports to authorise the imposi- tion of restrictions on a fundamental right in language wide enough to companyer restrictions both within and without

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overbroad language not severable under Art.13(1); covers permissible and impermissible; cannot uphold partial validity.

holdings.text: The application is therefore allowed and the order of the respondents prohibiting the entry and circulation of the petitioners journal in the State of Madras is hereby quashed.

anchor.surface_text: The application is therefore allowed and the order of the respondents prohibiting the entry and circulation of the petitioners journal in the State of Madras is hereby quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from invalidity of s.9(1-A); direct application to facts.

holdings.text: Disorders involving menace to the peace and tranquillity of the Province and affecting public safety undermine the security of the State; the impugned law satisfies Art.19(2); reliefs sought cannot be granted.
